question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
For \(\displaystyle f(x)\) to have continuous first derivatives, we must have \(\displaystyle p_i'(x_{i+1}) = p_{i+1}'(x_{i+1})\) . This gives us N-2 equations because we cannot fit the endpoints to anything.

For \(\displaystyle f(x)\) to have continuous second derivatives, we must have \(\displaystyle p_{i}''(x_{i+1}) = p_{i+1}''(x_{i+1})\) . This gives us N-2 equations because again, we cannot fit the endpoints to anything.

So in total, \(\displaystyle (N-2) + (N-2) = 2N - 4\) equations

statement_html:
Suppose you are given a set of N data points (xn, yn), with xn increasing, and you wish to interpolate these points with a spline function \(f\), where \(f\)(x) is given by the cubic polynomial pn(x) on each interval (xn, xn+1) for n = 1, ..., N-1:

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle p_n(x) = a_n(x-x_n)^3 + b_n(x-x_n)^2 + c_n(x-x_n) + d_n\end{aligned}\]

(b) Write down the equations required for \(f\)(x) to have continuous first and second derivatives. How many equations does this provide?
